Key Arguments: The definition of 'harm' in the legislation is vague and lacks transparency, making it difficult for citizens to understand and avoid causing harm.
The government or any appointed body should not have the power to dictate communication, as it infringes on free speech.
Historical advancements in science and health care have often come from questioning prevailing beliefs, which could be stifled by this legislation.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, censorship limited public access to scientific information, which is contrary to democratic principles.
The proposed fines in the legislation could disproportionately affect those who are not wealthy, limiting their ability to express opinions.
Main Themes: Vagueness and lack of clarity in legal definitions
Historical importance of questioning established norms
Economic inequality in the ability to express opinions
Notable Quotes: No government or appointed body should have the power to tell people what they should be communicating in any form.
Censorship of information and restriction of open and frank discussion is not acceptable in our country.
